skill.name: pubmed-database
skill.description: Direct REST API access to PubMed. Advanced Boolean/MeSH queries, E-utilities API, batch processing, citation management. For Python workflows, prefer biopython (Bio.Entrez). Use this for direct HTTP/REST work or custom API implementations.
skill.summary: Direct REST API access to PubMed. Advanced Boolean/MeSH queries, E-utilities API, batch processing, ...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation files. It provides guidance on constructing PubMed queries and using the NCBI E-utilities API. No executable code, scripts, network operations, or file system access is implemented. Users make their own API calls to the official NCBI endpoints.

content.value_statement: Finding relevant biomedical research is time-consuming. This skill provides advanced search techniques, MeSH term guidance, and E-utilities API documentation to quickly locate articles, clinical trials, and systematic reviews in PubMed's database of millions of citations.
actual_capabilities: Construct advanced Boolean queries with field tags and operators
Search using MeSH terms and controlled vocabulary
Access PubMed programmatically via E-utilities REST API
Find articles by author, journal, PMID, or DOI
Build systematic review search strategies using PICO framework
Filter results by publication type, date, and text availability
limitations: Does not execute API calls - users implement their own HTTP requests
No built-in citation management or export functionality
Rate limits enforced by NCBI (3-10 requests per second)
Access limited to PubMed citations - full text depends on publisher

use_cases.title: Systematic Literature Reviews
use_cases.description: Build comprehensive search strategies using MeSH terms and Boolean operators to find all relevant studies for systematic reviews.

use_cases.title: Evidence-Based Practice
use_cases.description: Quickly locate recent clinical trials, guidelines, and meta-analyses on treatments and diagnostic methods for patient care.

use_cases.title: Research Topic Exploration
use_cases.description: Discover published research on your topic, find key authors, and explore citation networks to understand the literature landscape.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Article Search
prompt_templates.scenario: Find recent research on a topic
prompt_templates.prompt: Search PubMed for recent articles on [TOPIC] from 2023-2024. Include systematic reviews and clinical trials.

prompt_templates.title: Clinical Question
prompt_templates.prompt: Find randomized controlled trials comparing [TREATMENT A] versus [TREATMENT B] for [CONDITION] published in the last 5 years.

prompt_templates.title: Author Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find publications by [AUTHOR NAME] on [TOPIC] in [YEAR]. Include their most cited papers.

prompt_templates.title: Systematic Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Construct a comprehensive PubMed search strategy using PICO framework for [CLINICAL QUESTION]. Include MeSH terms and synonyms.

output_examples.input: Find systematic reviews on diabetes treatment from 2023-2024
output: Query: diabetes mellitus[mh] AND treatment[tiab] AND systematic review[pt] AND 2023:2024[dp]
Result count shows total matching articles
Filter by free full text for immediate access

best_practices: Use MeSH terms with [mh] tag for consistent, comprehensive coverage of biomedical concepts
Include API key with E-utility requests to increase rate limits from 3 to 10 requests per second
Start broad then refine: begin with general terms, add field tags and filters to narrow results
Use history server (usehistory=y) for queries returning more than 500 articles
anti_patterns: Searching without field tags when precision is needed - automatic term mapping may produce unexpected results
Ignoring rate limits - excessive requests may result in temporary IP blocks from NCBI
Skipping date filters - retrieving thousands of irrelevant older articles instead of recent research
Using general search terms only - misses indexed MeSH terms that provide better coverage

faq.question: Is an API key required for PubMed?
faq.answer: Yes, NCBI requires API keys for E-utility calls. Keys are free and increase rate limits from 3 to 10 requests per second.

faq.question: What is the maximum results per search?
faq.answer: PubMed displays a maximum of 10,000 results. For larger datasets, use the history server with batch retrieval via EFetch.

faq.question: Can I search PubMed from Claude Code?
faq.answer: This skill provides query syntax and API guidance. You implement HTTP calls to NCBI endpoints using requests or similar libraries.

faq.question: Is my search data kept private?
faq.answer: Search queries to NCBI may be logged for service monitoring. No personal data is stored by PubMed beyond standard server logs.

faq.question: Why are some articles not accessible?
faq.answer: PubMed provides citations and abstracts. Full text access depends on publisher availability, institutional subscriptions, or open access status.

faq.question: How does this differ from biopython?
faq.answer: Biopython (Bio.Entrez) provides Python wrappers for E-utilities. This skill focuses on direct REST API usage for custom implementations.
